conclusion: A semi-circular wire frame with radius r is placed in a uniform magnetic field, perpendicular to the field direction, with points M and N connected to a DC power supply.
The Ampere force on the straight part of the wire frame is F, and the task is to find the total Ampere force on the entire frame.
Ampere force on a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field is given by F = I × L × B × sinθ, where θ is the angle between the current direction and magnetic field.
Since the wire frame is perpendicular to the magnetic field, sin(θ) = 1 for all segments.
The straight segment MN has a length of 2r, which is the diameter of the semi-circle.
The force on the straight part MN is F = I × (2r) × B.
The semi-circular part has a length of πr, which is half the circumference of a circle.
The current I is the same throughout the wire, and the magnetic field B is uniform.
The force on the semi-circular part is F_semi = I × πr × B.
The direction of forces is crucial: for the straight segment MN, the force is perpendicular to both the current and the magnetic field.
For the semi-circular segment, the force at each point is perpendicular to the local current direction, and the horizontal components cancel out, leaving only a vertical component.
The net force from the semi-circular part is F_semi-net = ∫(0 to π) I B r cosθ dθ = 2IBr, which equals the force on the straight part F.
The total force on the entire wire frame is F_total = F + F = 2F.
The magnitude of the Ampere force acting on the entire wire frame is 2F.
